Award.AwardTitle: Acquisition of a Zeta Potential and Particle Size Analyzer for Interdisciplinary Undergraduate Research and Education at the Inter American University of Puerto Rico, Ponce Campus
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award is supported by the Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) and the Chemistry Research Instrumentation (CRIF) Programs. Professor Merlis Alvarez-Berrios from the Inter American University Puerto Rico, Ponce Campus and colleague Edmy Ferrer-Torres have acquired a zeta potential and particle size analyzer. The zeta potential is a term used in the electrokinetic studies of colloidal dispersions. This instrument is also used in the investigation of very small aggregates called nanoparticles. It is used to determine particle size and zeta potential critical for understanding of various materials. The size of nanoparticles plays a key role in their unique properties. The zeta potential value is related to the stability of nanoparticles and hence their product performance. Moreover, the analyzer provides multiple accessories and therefore is suitable for a wide spectrum of user applications. These characterization studies are crucial for evaluating the potential application of novel materials in areas such as medicine, technology and the petroleum field. One application is the study of microparticle-protein interactions which may be of potential interest in medicine. The instrument also contributes to training students in modern instrumentation. It is supporting interdisciplinary undergraduate research and education at the Inter American University of Puerto Rico, at both the Ponce Campus and San German campuses, as well as high schools and colleges from the south region of Puerto Rico.

The instrument is employed in supporting research in a number of projects to accurately predict and quantify the stability of nanoparticles. Metallic nanoparticles are of special interest in these studies. The instrument is being used to elucidate protein-protein and microparticle-protein interactions governing the inhibition of fibrillation processes. Modification of solid surfaces is being studied. Confirmation of the functional groups present on the surface of the nanomaterials suspended in liquids after chemical modification is under investigation. The instrument is also being used to determine the electrostatic interactions between particles and flat surfaces.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The undergraduate research program at IAUPR-Ponce campus has had significant accomplishments using the zeta potential & particle size analyzer acquired with MRI NSF funding. Students and faculty from the Department of Science and Technology have made discoveries that involve the design of nanoparticles/microparticles for biomedical applications and use of endemic plants from PR to treat Alzheimer’s disease. The nano- and microplatforms developed may decrease the side effects of toxic drugs (such as amphotericin B) overcoming significant limitations exhibited by clinically relevant therapeutics. These vehicles and synthesis methods may reduce the main side effects induced by current formulations without compromising their effectiveness. Therefore, they could be evaluated with drugs that are used to treat other diseases. Extracts from Puerto Rican plants will lead to the development of novel therapeutics with the ability to successfully treat Alzheimer’s disease (AD). These extracts demonstrated to be effective in inhibiting beta amyloid fibrils which are responsible for Alzheimer’s disease. These advancements will eventually impact the clinical care of deadly diseases in USA and global populations.

The innovative results obtained resulted in one peer reviewed publication and twelve presentations at local, regional and national scientific conferences. Moreover, the quality of these projects has been recognized at national conferences such as the Annual Biomedical Research Conference for Minority Students (a student received an award for best research project and oral presentation in Chemistry).

The quality of research and educational training of our students who are the future instrumentalists has been improved. The research projects enabled by the instrument provided undergraduate students with opportunities for hands-on training and research experiences in several areas such as nanomaterials, materials science and protein analysis; therefore, increasing students’ understanding of core concepts in the field. Additionally, the instrument was used to teach and complement courses related to Biochemistry. High school students and teachers from the south of Puerto Rico were exposed to research findings and participated in a workshop related to the use of the equipment. For its technical feature, the acquisition of this equipment has improved the quality of research and educational training of our students and has allowed us to prepare a much larger cross-section of the U.S. population with the sciences and engineering knowledge necessary to function in a highly technological society and to maintain the momentum of discovery and innovation that will further the nation’s economic prosperity.

The acquisition of the zeta potential and particle size analyzer has also strengthened collaborations with other campuses in Puerto Rico and USA which has allowed us to prepare competitive proposals to provide our students exceptional research experiences that will improve their skills and professional capabilities.
